tweet: To prevent future incidents, I will be requesting that @Amtrak CEO Richard Anderson meet with me to discuss eliminating Amtrak’s nationwide policy of refusing to absorb any costs associated with reconfiguring a railcar to accommodate a group of wheelchair users. (4/4)
As Ranking Member of the @commercedems Subcommittee on Transportation, I believe Amtrak must do better moving forward. (3/4)

The Americans with Disabilities Act has been the law of the land for 30 years. Yet in 2020, @Amtrak believes it would be an unreasonable burden to remove architectural barriers that would enable a group with five wheelchair users to travel together. (2/4)

It is outrageous that @Amtrak asked a group of passengers from @AccessLiving to pay $25,000 to ride from Chicago to Bloomington, IL. It is also disappointing that @Amtrak leadership appears to have failed to offer a public apology for its initial mistake. (1/4) https://twitter.com/NPRJoeShapiro/status/1218390862310387718 …

I don’t understand why some of my colleagues on the other side of the aisle are so scared of being asked questions by reporters. If only someone could ask them. #FirstAmendment #FreePress https://twitter.com/MelissaQuinn97/status/1217849087413903362 …

I'll be pushing hard for witnesses & documents so that I—& all Americans—can carefully review the underlying evidence for each article.

Throughout the process, I will be an impartial juror as I carry out the weighty responsibility that now rests on my shoulders as a US Senator.

I will be an impartial juror. To do that, it’s critical that we have witnesses and documents so we can review all the evidence of the case. Then, and only then, can we deliberate. 

Because: *trials have witnesses and cover-ups do not*

Today, as the impeachment trial begins in the Senate, I will raise my right hand and once again to swear an oath to this nation. This time I swear to do impartial justice according to the Constitution and laws. pic.twitter.com/m1vW1CKPNX

Transparency is critical to any functioning democracy and we should do everything in our power to increase, not decrease, it. These restrictions on the free press are un-American. https://twitter.com/politico/status/1217565961315868673 …

This agreement is not perfect. A stronger one would've addressed – or even mentioned – climate change. Nonetheless, I view it as much-improved from what the Trump Admin initially proposed and a very positive development in creating a more just trade policy for American workers.

The final agreement also includes increased market access for IL wheat producers & maintains tariff-free access to crucial ag markets for IL soybeans, corn, beef & pork producers. Passage of #USMCA will provide greater stability and certainty for farmers and manufacturers alike.

For the first time, working families in Illinois will see Congress vote on a trade pact that allows strong and swift enforcement actions against producers who deny their workers the right to collectively bargain—a major victory for workers in my state and across the country.

Today, as the result of the work of Congressional Democrats, we have a #USMCA that works for farmers and manufacturers and features enforceable labor standards to support American workers. https://www.duckworth.senate.gov/news/press-releases/duckworth-to-support-bipartisan-us-mexico-canada-agreement …

Today I joined @RepCasten and @SenatorDurbin in writing to @BetsyDeVosED to ban the practice of isolation rooms in schools. The whole Indo-Pacific region is vitally important to our national interests and we should be doing more to strengthen and support our partnerships in Southeast Asia. I look forward to working with Ambassador DeSombre to advance the U.S.-Thai relationship.

My bipartisan bill is endorsed by the American Jail Association and the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, among many others. Passing my bill will help end predatory call rates and help reduce recidivism.

Read more about my bill here: https://www.duckworth.senate.gov/news/press-releases/duckworth-portman-booker-schatz-markey-and-king-introduce-bipartisan-bill-to-address-predatory-phone-rates-in-criminal-justice-system …

I'll continue working to reform our criminal justice system and I’m pleased a bipartisan coalition of Senators representing Americans from Ohio to Hawaii, Tennessee, Maine and more, helped me introduce the bipartisan Martha Wright-Reed Just and Reasonable Communications Act.

Sadly, these stories are all too common. Picking up a phone and calling loved ones may sound simple, but for the more than 2 million incarcerated individuals in America, it's nearly impossible due to the high costs of placing a phone call from a prison or jail. https://twitter.com/NBCNews/status/1212530962330005504 …

With his strike on Soleimani, Trump villainized the US and victimized Iran, isolating us from our longtime partner in Iraq and amping up Iran’s influence in a country everyone knows is vital to our security interests throughout the Middle East. My op-ed for @ChicagoTribune: https://twitter.com/chicagotribune/status/1216170435794145285 …

Our Constitution requires President Trump take care that the laws be faithfully executed. 

That is why I'm asking @EsperDoD a simple question: why does @DeptofDefense believe the January 3rd military operation Trump ordered was legal? https://www.duckworth.senate.gov/news/press-releases/duckworth-demands-secretary-esper-disclose-why-dod-believes-killing-soleimani-was-legal …

We know by now that we can't trust the Trump admin to tell the truth about the reasons behind last week's actions in the Middle East. This is the latest proof that Congress must be brought into the fold so we can do our Constitutional duty of debating & deciding matters of war. https://twitter.com/CNN/status/1215709983603642371 …
Until the day—the hour—that we vote, the American people should keep holding every single one of us in Congress accountable for carrying out that most solemn responsibility: the power to declare war.

Truly honoring the sacrifices of our troops *requires* Congress to do its job as a coequal branch of government. We need to debate and vote on whether to use military force, and if the answer is that we should, then we must provide our troops with a clearly-defined mission.

It’s outrageous that a) this administration still refuses to provide the evidence that would justify why it's so willing to lead us to the brink of war, and b) that it's trying to intimidate Congress from performing its Constitutional duty of debating matters of war & peace.
Just over a week after Trump decided to launch the strike that killed Soleimani, one thing is clear: Americans are less safe today than they were eight days ago.

Full transparency from Boeing is long overdue, and the Senate should hold additional hearings to ensure it is complying with ongoing investigations and pursuing the highest aviation safety standards moving forward. (4/4)

...than to provide federal and congressional investigators with critical information up front. That’s not just troubling, but completely unacceptable and raises the question of what else might be around the corner in this ongoing saga. (3/4)

Once again, it appears that Boeing’s stated commitment to transparency and accountability in the 737 MAX investigation is betrayed by its actions and suggests Boeing executives are making a calculation that it is better to acknowledge and apologize after the fact... (2/4)

These internal staff communications reflect a corporate culture that downplays safety and training in an effort to reduce costs and avoid delays during the development of Boeing’s aircraft. (1/4) https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1215589124960333826 …

I'm on the Senate floor to talk about last night's attacks on Iraqi bases housing U.S. troops and to highlight this Administrations utter lack of a realistic, strategic plan to deal with the situation they created by striking Soleimani. Tune in:  https://www.c-span.org/video/?467921-1/senate-session …

Moving forward, we need to focus on how we achieve our security goals—&recognize those goals do not include trading missiles w/Iran. Trump needs to a) come up w/a realistic strategic plan for the region and b) bring it to Congress for approval so we can do our Constitutional duty

We should be doing whatever we can to break this cycle of escalation—but right now, it’s not clear this administration has the competence to work towards deescalation. We need less chest thumping and more diplomacy.

Thinking of our troops in harm's way tonight & hope they are able to stay safe. The attacks tonight underscores the fact that the strike that killed #Soleimani didn't make our troops — or any American — any safer. https://twitter.com/chicagotribune/status/1214695328852656129 …

Devastating. Thinking of everyone in #PuertoRico impacted by the earthquake and power outages. Let’s help our fellow Americans rebuild their homes and communities. https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1214482874008788992 …

Going on #AMR to discuss the Soleimani strike & current situation w/Iraq & Iran. No President has the authority to draw us into another war without Congressional approval. Trump owes it to our troops, Constitution & all Americans to let Congress perform its duties. Tune in.

I’m saddened to learn Army Specialist Henry Mayfield, Jr., was killed in action this weekend in Kenya. My deepest condolences to his friends, family and loved ones back home in Illinois who lost their brother, their son and their friend. https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/suburban-army-specialist-killed-in-attack-at-kenya-airfield-family-says/2196847/ …

That’s unacceptable. Donald Trump owes it to our troops and to our Constitution to follow the law, provide the American people the transparency they deserve and ensure Congress is able to perform its Constitutional duties.

This solemn duty is solely for Congress to decide, but the Trump Administration appears to have failed to inform the people’s representatives of his actions and, in doing so, may very well lead us to war.

There is no question that Iranian Major General Soleimani posed a threat to the free world, but there is also no question that the President—any President—does not have Constitutional authority to draw the United States into a war without prior Congressional approval.

I first ran for office to ensure that when the drums of war beat loudly in Washington, I would be able to remind my colleagues in Congress and the White House what the true costs of war actually are—not just in dollars, but in American troops’ lives as well. (1/4) https://twitter.com/voxdotcom/status/1213094928890368000 …
